p: The ACE2-SARS/COVID-19 interplay has led to controversy with clinical implications. The finding that ACE2 KO mice are protected against SARS-CoV infection [ 17] raises a concern that an upregulated ACE2 is harmful in the setting of SARS-CoV and COVID infections, as the virus cannot enter the cell. Conversely, ACE2 downregulation following infection is concerning considering the preclinical data summarised to this point, which instead suggests a putative causative mechanism of Ang II/Ang (1â€“7) in the evolution of SARS-CoV-2 associated acute lung injury. Even if abolishing ACE2 were feasible, Han et al. detected alternative receptors, DC/L-SIGN, which mediated SARS-CoV entry independently of ACE2 [ 21].
